gospel.text:
[[Lc 22,14]]When the hour came, Jesus took his place at table with the apostles.
[[Lc 22,15]]He said to them, "I have eagerly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer,
[[Lc 22,16]]for, I tell you, I shall not eat it (again) until there is fulfillment in the kingdom of God."
[[Lc 22,17]]Then he took a cup, gave thanks, and said, "Take this and share it among yourselves;
[[Lc 22,18]]for I tell you (that) from this time on I shall not drink of the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes."
[[Lc 22,19]]Then he took the bread, said the blessing, broke it, and gave it to them, saying, "This is my body, which will be given for you; do this in memory of me."
[[Lc 22,20]]And likewise the cup after they had eaten, saying, "This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which will be shed for you.
[[Lc 22,21]]And yet behold, the hand of the one who is to betray me is with me on the table;
[[Lc 22,22]]for the Son of Man indeed goes as it has been determined; but woe to that man by whom he is betrayed."
[[Lc 22,23]]And they began to debate among themselves who among them would do such a deed.
[[Lc 22,24]]Then an argument broke out among them about which of them should be regarded as the greatest.
[[Lc 22,25]]He said to them, "The kings of the Gentiles lord it over them and those in authority over them are addressed as 'Benefactors';
[[Lc 22,26]]but among you it shall not be so. Rather, let the greatest among you be as the youngest, and the leader as the servant.
[[Lc 22,27]]For who is greater: the one seated at table or the one who serves? Is it not the one seated at table? I am among you as the one who serves.
[[Lc 22,28]]It is you who have stood by me in my trials;
[[Lc 22,29]]and I confer a kingdom on you, just as my Father has conferred one on me,
[[Lc 22,30]]that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom; and you will sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
[[Lc 22,31]]Simon, Simon, behold Satan has demanded to sift all of you like wheat,
[[Lc 22,32]]but I have prayed that your own faith may not fail; and once you have turned back, you must strengthen your brothers."
[[Lc 22,33]]He said to him, "Lord, I am prepared to go to prison and to die with you."
[[Lc 22,34]]But he replied, "I tell you, Peter, before the cock crows this day, you will deny three times that you know me."
[[Lc 22,35]]He said to them, "When I sent you forth without a money bag or a sack or sandals, were you in need of anything?" "No, nothing," they replied.
[[Lc 22,36]]He said to them, "But now one who has a money bag should take it, and likewise a sack, and one who does not have a sword should sell his cloak and buy one.
[[Lc 22,37]]For I tell you that this scripture must be fulfilled in me, namely, 'He was counted among the wicked'; and indeed what is written about me is coming to fulfillment."
[[Lc 22,38]]Then they said, "Lord, look, there are two swords here." But he replied, "It is enough!"
[[Lc 22,39]]Then going out he went, as was his custom, to the Mount of Olives, and the disciples followed him.
[[Lc 22,40]]When he arrived at the place he said to them, "Pray that you may not undergo the test."
[[Lc 22,41]]After withdrawing about a stone's throw from them and kneeling, he prayed,
[[Lc 22,42]]saying, "Father, if you are willing, take this cup away from me; still, not my will but yours be done."
[[Lc 22,43]](And to strengthen him an angel from heaven appeared to him.
[[Lc 22,44]]He was in such agony and he prayed so fervently that his sweat became like drops of blood falling on the ground.)
[[Lc 22,45]]When he rose from prayer and returned to his disciples, he found them sleeping from grief.
[[Lc 22,46]]He said to them, "Why are you sleeping? Get up and pray that you may not undergo the test."
[[Lc 22,47]]While he was still speaking, a crowd approached and in front was one of the Twelve, a man named Judas. He went up to Jesus to kiss him.
[[Lc 22,48]]Jesus said to him, "Judas, are you betraying the Son of Man with a kiss?"
[[Lc 22,49]]His disciples realized what was about to happen, and they asked, "Lord, shall we strike with a sword?"
[[Lc 22,50]]And one of them struck the high priest's servant and cut off his right ear.
[[Lc 22,51]]But Jesus said in reply, "Stop, no more of this!" Then he touched the servant's ear and healed him.
[[Lc 22,52]]And Jesus said to the chief priests and temple guards and elders who had come for him, "Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs?
[[Lc 22,53]]Day after day I was with you in the temple area, and you did not seize me; but this is your hour, the time for the power of darkness."
[[Lc 22,54]]After arresting him they led him away and took him into the house of the high priest; Peter was following at a distance.
[[Lc 22,55]]They lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat around it, and Peter sat down with them.
[[Lc 22,56]]When a maid saw him seated in the light, she looked intently at him and said, "This man too was with him."
[[Lc 22,57]]But he denied it saying, "Woman, I do not know him."
[[Lc 22,58]]A short while later someone else saw him and said, "You too are one of them"; but Peter answered, "My friend, I am not."
[[Lc 22,59]]About an hour later, still another insisted, "Assuredly, this man too was with him, for he also is a Galilean."
[[Lc 22,60]]But Peter said, "My friend, I do not know what you are talking about." Just as he was saying this, the cock crowed,
[[Lc 22,61]]and the Lord turned and looked at Peter; and Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how he had said to him, "Before the cock crows today, you will deny me three times."
[[Lc 22,62]]He went out and began to weep bitterly.
[[Lc 22,63]]The men who held Jesus in custody were ridiculing and beating him.
[[Lc 22,64]]They blindfolded him and questioned him, saying, "Prophesy! Who is it that struck you?"
[[Lc 22,65]]And they reviled him in saying many other things against him.
[[Lc 22,66]]When day came the council of elders of the people met, both chief priests and scribes, and they brought him before their Sanhedrin.
[[Lc 22,67]]They said, "If you are the Messiah, tell us," but he replied to them, "If I tell you, you will not believe,
[[Lc 22,68]]and if I question, you will not respond.
[[Lc 22,69]]But from this time on the Son of Man will be seated at the right hand of the power of God."
[[Lc 22,70]]They all asked, "Are you then the Son of God?" He replied to them, "You say that I am."
[[Lc 22,71]]Then they said, "What further need have we for testimony? We have heard it from his own mouth."
[[Lc 23,1]]Then the whole assembly of them arose and brought him before Pilate.
[[Lc 23,2]]They brought charges against him, saying, "We found this man misleading our people; he opposes the payment of taxes to Caesar and maintains that he is the Messiah, a king."
[[Lc 23,3]]Pilate asked him, "Are you the king of the Jews?" He said to him in reply, "You say so."
[[Lc 23,4]]Pilate then addressed the chief priests and the crowds, "I find this man not guilty."
[[Lc 23,5]]But they were adamant and said, "He is inciting the people with his teaching throughout all Judea, from Galilee where he began even to here."
[[Lc 23,6]]On hearing this Pilate asked if the man was a Galilean;
[[Lc 23,7]]and upon learning that he was under Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod who was in Jerusalem at that time.
[[Lc 23,8]]Herod was very glad to see Jesus; he had been wanting to see him for a long time, for he had heard about him and had been hoping to see him perform some sign.
[[Lc 23,9]]He questioned him at length, but he gave him no answer.
[[Lc 23,10]]The chief priests and scribes, meanwhile, stood by accusing him harshly.
[[Lc 23,11]](Even) Herod and his soldiers treated him contemptuously and mocked him, and after clothing him in resplendent garb, he sent him back to Pilate.
[[Lc 23,12]]Herod and Pilate became friends that very day, even though they had been enemies formerly.
[[Lc 23,13]]Pilate then summoned the chief priests, the rulers, and the people
[[Lc 23,14]]and said to them, "You brought this man to me and accused him of inciting the people to revolt. I have conducted my investigation in your presence and have not found this man guilty of the charges you have brought against him,
[[Lc 23,15]]nor did Herod, for he sent him back to us. So no capital crime has been committed by him.
[[Lc 23,16]]Therefore I shall have him flogged and then release him."
[[Lc 23,17]]
[[Lc 23,18]]But all together they shouted out, "Away with this man! Release Barabbas to us."
[[Lc 23,19]](Now Barabbas had been imprisoned for a rebellion that had taken place in the city and for murder.)
[[Lc 23,20]]Again Pilate addressed them, still wishing to release Jesus,
[[Lc 23,21]]but they continued their shouting, "Crucify him! Crucify him!"
[[Lc 23,22]]Pilate addressed them a third time, "What evil has this man done? I found him guilty of no capital crime. Therefore I shall have him flogged and then release him."
[[Lc 23,23]]With loud shouts, however, they persisted in calling for his crucifixion, and their voices prevailed.
[[Lc 23,24]]The verdict of Pilate was that their demand should be granted.
[[Lc 23,25]]So he released the man who had been imprisoned for rebellion and murder, for whom they asked, and he handed Jesus over to them to deal with as they wished.
[[Lc 23,26]]As they led him away they took hold of a certain Simon, a Cyrenian, who was coming in from the country; and after laying the cross on him, they made him carry it behind Jesus.
[[Lc 23,27]]A large crowd of people followed Jesus, including many women who mourned and lamented him.
[[Lc 23,28]]Jesus turned to them and said, "Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me; weep instead for yourselves and for your children,
[[Lc 23,29]]for indeed, the days are coming when people will say, 'Blessed are the barren, the wombs that never bore and the breasts that never nursed.'
[[Lc 23,30]]At that time people will say to the mountains, 'Fall upon us!' and to the hills, 'Cover us!'
[[Lc 23,31]]for if these things are done when the wood is green what will happen when it is dry?"
[[Lc 23,32]]Now two others, both criminals, were led away with him to be executed.
[[Lc 23,33]]When they came to the place called the Skull, they crucified him and the criminals there, one on his right, the other on his left.
[[Lc 23,34]](Then Jesus said, "Father, forgive them, they know not what they do.") They divided his garments by casting lots.
[[Lc 23,35]]The people stood by and watched; the rulers, meanwhile, sneered at him and said, "He saved others, let him save himself if he is the chosen one, the Messiah of God."
[[Lc 23,36]]Even the soldiers jeered at him. As they approached to offer him wine
[[Lc 23,37]]they called out, "If you are King of the Jews, save yourself."
[[Lc 23,38]]Above him there was an inscription that read, "This is the King of the Jews."
[[Lc 23,39]]Now one of the criminals hanging there reviled Jesus, saying, "Are you not the Messiah? Save yourself and us."
[[Lc 23,40]]The other, however, rebuking him, said in reply, "Have you no fear of God, for you are subject to the same condemnation?
[[Lc 23,41]]And indeed, we have been condemned justly, for the sentence we received corresponds to our crimes, but this man has done nothing criminal."
[[Lc 23,42]]Then he said, "Jesus, remember me when you come into your kingdom."
[[Lc 23,43]]He replied to him, "Amen, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise."
[[Lc 23,44]]It was now about noon and darkness came over the whole land until three in the afternoon
[[Lc 23,45]]because of an eclipse of the sun. Then the veil of the temple was torn down the middle.
[[Lc 23,46]]Jesus cried out in a loud voice, "Father, into your hands I commend my spirit"; and when he had said this he breathed his last.
[[Lc 23,47]]The centurion who witnessed what had happened glorified God and said, "This man was innocent beyond doubt."
[[Lc 23,48]]When all the people who had gathered for this spectacle saw what had happened, they returned home beating their breasts;
[[Lc 23,49]]but all his acquaintances stood at a distance, including the women who had followed him from Galilee and saw these events.
[[Lc 23,50]]Now there was a virtuous and righteous man named Joseph who, though he was a member of the council,
[[Lc 23,51]]had not consented to their plan of action. He came from the Jewish town of Arimathea and was awaiting the kingdom of God.
[[Lc 23,52]]He went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
[[Lc 23,53]]After he had taken the body down, he wrapped it in a linen cloth and laid him in a rock-hewn tomb in which no one had yet been buried.
[[Lc 23,54]]It was the day of preparation, and the sabbath was about to begin.
[[Lc 23,55]]The women who had come from Galilee with him followed behind, and when they had seen the tomb and the way in which his body was laid in it,
[[Lc 23,56]]they returned and prepared spices and perfumed oils. Then they rested on the sabbath according to the commandment.
gospel.title: Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint Luke

first_reading.text:
[[Is 50,4]]The Lord GOD has given me a well-trained tongue, That I might know how to speak to the weary a word that will rouse them. Morning after morning he opens my ear that I may hear;
[[Is 50,5]]And I have not rebelled, have not turned back.
[[Is 50,6]]I gave my back to those who beat me, my cheeks to those who plucked my beard; My face I did not shield from buffets and spitting.
[[Is 50,7]]The Lord GOD is my help, therefore I am not disgraced; I have set my face like flint, knowing that I shall not be put to shame.
first_reading.title: Book of Isaiah

second_reading.text:
[[Ph 2,6]]Christ Jesus, though he was in the form of God, did not regard equality with God something to be grasped.
[[Ph 2,7]]Rather, he emptied himself, taking the form of a slave, coming in human likeness; and found human in appearance,
[[Ph 2,8]]he humbled himself, becoming obedient to death, even death on a cross.
[[Ph 2,9]]Because of this, God greatly exalted him and bestowed on him the name that is above every name,
[[Ph 2,10]]that at the name of Jesus every knee should bend, of those in heaven and on earth and under the earth,
[[Ph 2,11]]and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.
second_reading.title: Letter to the Philippians
